title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Congress finds that public confidence in the Federal Government relies on officers and employees avoiding conflicts of interest, especially concerning political fundraising. The Supreme Court's Citizens United decision has led to a significant increase in corporate political spending, with some contributions being made to entities under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The increase in corporate political spending, including anonymous contributions to entities under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code, raises concerns about conflicts of interest. Current financial disclosure requirements do not cover donations to political action committees or certain entities, highlighting the need for public disclosure to address conflicts of interest through ethics agreements. SEC. 3. DISCLOSURE OF CERTAIN TYPES OF CONTRIBUTIONS. Definitions in the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 are amended to include the term "covered contribution" as a payment or deposit of money made by or on behalf of a covered individual to a political organization or specific types of organizations. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 defines a "covered contribution" as a payment made by a covered individual to certain organizations, including those that promote or oppose changes in Federal laws or regulations relevant to the agency where the individual is nominated or serving. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 defines a "covered contribution" as a payment made by a covered individual to organizations that promote or oppose changes in Federal laws or regulations relevant to the agency where the individual is nominated or serving. This includes contributions solicited in writing by or on behalf of the individual and made to a political organization subject to Federal laws or regulations administered by the agency. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 defines a "covered contribution" as a payment made by a covered individual to political organizations subject to Federal laws or regulations. This includes payments to organizations described in specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code that are exempt from tax. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 defines a "covered contribution" as a payment made by a covered individual to political organizations subject to Federal laws or regulations. A covered individual is someone nominated or appointed to a covered position, which includes specific positions in the government hierarchy. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 outlines positions that are considered covered, including those in the Executive Schedule, Senior Executive Service, and schedule C of the Code of Federal Regulations. Disclosure requirements are amended under section 101 of the Act. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 has disclosure requirements amended under section 101, including provisions for individuals leaving non-covered positions and assuming covered positions. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 requires individuals in covered positions to file a report within 30 days of assuming the position, including specific information. Amendments also include inserting additional information requirements in various subsections. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 requires individuals in covered positions to file reports with specific information within 30 days of assuming the position. Recent amendments include adding details in subsection (j) regarding applicable periods and covered gifts. The Ethics in Government Act of 1978 mandates covered individuals to report covered contributions, including dates, values, and parties involved, within specific timeframes. Covered contributions solicited must include the value, name of the contributor, and recipient. Contributions made by or on behalf of a covered individual may pose a conflict of interest, but exemptions can be granted by the Director of the Office of Government Ethics. Reports filed by covered individuals must include information on covered gifts received. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics shall provide reports and ethics agreements to Congress upon request within 30 days. Rules on ethics agreements will be issued promptly by the Director. The Director of the Office of Government Ethics will issue rules on how agencies in the executive branch should handle disclosed information when drafting ethics agreements with appointed individuals.
